title: Artificial intelligence helps break barriers for Hispanic homeownership
description: Some mortgage experts are using AI tools to help limited-English homebuyers navigate the loan application process.
content:
For many Hispanics the road to homeownership is filled with obstacles, including loan officers who don’t speak Spanish or aren’t familiar with buyers who may not fit the boxes of a traditional mortgage applicant.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Revolutionizing Every Aspect of Life - India Unveils Its First Homegrown AI Chips, Paving the Way for a Self-Reliant Tech Future
description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly redefining the way we live, work, and interact. title: AI chip designed by IIT innovator unveiled at T
description: India's indigenously designed Artificial Intelligence (AI) chips, developed with homegrown technology and talent, have been unveiled by innovators at the T-CHIP Semicon Constitution Summit in Hyderabad. These chips, built entirely in Telangana, mark a step in creating a self-reliant semiconductor ecosystem in the country.

title: GE Aerospace's AI-Powered Flight: India-Driven Innovations in Aircraft Engines
description: GE Aerospace is leveraging artificial intelligence at its John F Welch Technology Centre in Bengaluru to enhance aircraft engine design and maintenance. The centre's innovations have led to over 1,000 patents and contributions to advanced engine technologies, including hybrid and alternative fuels, highlighting India's pivotal role in global aviation advancements.

title: UAE President Sheikh Mohamed meets OpenAI CEO Sam Altman; awarded honorary doctorate for AI leadership
description: Middle East News: UAE President Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan meets with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman to discuss AI research and innovation partnerships, highlighting the UAE's commitment to becoming a global AI leader. Sam Altman awarded honorary doctorate for AI leadership by Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence (MBZUAI)

title: AI users more inclined to dishonesty, study finds
description: People who rely on artificial intelligence (AI) at work or school are more likely than others to "cheat," according to a team of French and German researchers.
content:
